title: 107_hr613
content: The "Character Learning and Student Success Act of 2001" (CLASS Act of 2001) grants initiatives for character education. The "Character Learning and Student Success Act of 2001" emphasizes the importance of character education in schools. It aims to improve students' ethical values and virtues, promoting a compassionate and responsible society. Character education integrates positive ethical traits into the regular school curriculum, increasing students' self-esteem and reducing the risk of harmful behavior. The existing curriculum and daily activities promote core ethical values and virtues in students, fostering a community of responsible individuals. States and local educational agencies are increasingly supporting character education initiatives, requiring access to effective methodologies and professional development opportunities. A central source of information on character education activities is becoming essential as implementation continues. The Secretary is authorized to make a 5-year grant to an organization with expertise in providing comprehensive information on character education policies, initiatives, and curricula. The organization must have a representative membership and a history of promoting quality character education initiatives. The grant recipient must develop initiatives that address core ethical values, emphasize student motivation and behavior, promote schools as caring communities, allow students to practice character lessons, involve families and communities, focus on leadership, service, and teamwork, and evaluate the effectiveness of character education programs. The grant recipient must develop character education initiatives focusing on core ethical values, student motivation, and behavior. Grant funds are used for information dissemination on quality character education methods, professional development models, assessment techniques, integration into educational content, and provision of services like a searchable database. The grantee must provide a searchable database with information on character education groups, curricula, books, and videos, a checklist for schools to assess curricula, an index of character education websites, and telephone assistance. They must also submit an annual report detailing the progress of the grant, including the number and types of information requests received. The grantee must provide a searchable database with information on character education groups, curricula, books, and videos, a checklist for schools to assess curricula, an index of character education websites, and telephone assistance. They must also submit an annual report detailing the progress of the grant, including the number and types of information requests received. The section also requires the grantee to identify unmet and future information needs in character education and provide a detailed account of the use of grant funds. Authorization of appropriations is set at $750,000 for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006. SEC. 3. GRANT TO CONDUCT CHARACTER EDUCATION RESEARCH. Congress finds that there is a lack of reporting on the impact of character education initiatives in schools, with unknown numbers of schools implementing such programs and their success. The needs of schools already implementing character education and those yet to start are not identified. Efforts are needed to assess the extent and effectiveness of character education in schools using Federal funds. The Secretary is authorized to grant funds for character education research. The Secretary is authorized to make a 5-year grant to an organization demonstrating expertise in character education research and practice, with a partnership with an institution of higher education. The grant recipient must assess schools' character education initiatives and classify them. The grant recipient must assess schools' character education initiatives, classify them, and submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing research progress, results, future needs, and fund usage. The grant recipient must provide a detailed account of fund usage under this section, with $700,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an "eligible organization" is defined as a tax-exempt organization under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code that has submitted a grant application to the Secretary. A "local educational agency" is defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and a "school" includes elementary schools as defined by the same Act. A school, as defined by the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, includes elementary and secondary schools. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education.
